title: Reduced Tillage Systems for Organic Vegetable Production

tasks.task: Conducting a research update on reduced tillage systems for organic vegetable production.
subtasks: Acknowledge funding sources (Ceres Trust and North Central SARE).
Explain the purpose of no-till and strip-till systems in organic production.
Describe the cover crop species and seeding rates (rye and vetch with specific weights).
Detail the timing and methods of cover crop termination (mechanical rolling with a roller crimper).
Differentiate between three whole plot treatments (no-till, strip-till, and conventional till).
Compare and contrast nitrogen fertilization strategies (full vs. two-thirds rate with fertigation).
Discuss the current stage of the study (early harvest) and the hypothesis for yield comparison.
Highlight the importance of reduced nitrate leaching in no-till and strip-till systems (using lysimeter data).

tasks.task: Describing the implementation and tools used in the strip-till and no-till treatments.
subtasks: Explain the conventional till plot without cover crops, requiring rototiller weed control.
Describe the strip-till process using the Hineker 6000 strip tiller, including components and setup.
Detail the role of row cleaners, coulters, subsoil shanks, and rolling baskets in strip tilling.
Outline the timing of strip tillage operations (fall termination and pre-planting for weed control, fluffing, and fertilization).

tasks.task: Demonstrating the use of the roller crimper.
subtasks: Introduce the INJ model roller crimper designed for organic no-till systems.
Describe the construction and operation of the roller crimper (barrel with chevron blades, weight option, and filling mechanism).

tasks.task: Description of the research location and setup.
subtasks: Provide the date and location (August 13th at the Horticulture Research Station in Ames, Iowa).
Present the aims of the Sustainable Vegetable Production Lab research on reduced tillage for organic production.
